item.title: Need help with somehing about edgeville
item.dc:creator: @slomifier slomifier
item.description:
@slomifier wrote:

I had this problem to, so I put this is my public boolean where i used it a lot:

//BR, TL, BL, TR

Obviously, BR would mean Bottom Right, and TL means Top Left etc.

So to get the first coord, go to the Bottom right of the area you want to use, then for the second coord, find the coords of the Top Left of the area and so on.

This means the first coord is BR, the second is TL and so on.

This is the “frame” I used, idk if it’s the same as yours"

if (absY >= COORD1 && absY <= COORD2 && absX >= COORD3 && absX <= COORD4){

I kinda rushed this so sorry if it’s messy.

Read full topic

sabsabi:

okay… but i dont understand !! ABSX WHERE TO WHERE AND WHERE TO WHERE??[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 18, 2008, 03:19:18 pm[/size][hr]i wanna make the whole edgeville…? can you help me?

Ugh, ok go to one corner of Edgeville get the coordinates using ::Mypos. Then go to another corner. Then at the top, and the other side. if you still cant understand then I will draw a picture.

item.title: Need help with somehing about edgeville
item.dc:creator: @hasumon hasumon
item.description:
@hasumon wrote:

This is like Algrebra College Course to you right?

absX >=

You see this? now look at

>=

What does this mean? It means GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO So we can do this such as

5 >= 1

Which makes this statement/expression correct but if its like this

3 >= 5

It is false so now do you understand?

item.title: Need help with somehing about edgeville
item.dc:creator: @Project_Evolution Project Evolution
item.description:
@Project_Evolution wrote:

Think of it as a box. Once you get a first coordinate then you put in the X and Y coordinate. Example,

Say the X coord is 2134.
Say the Y coord is 3300.

Do this;

if((absX >= 2134 && absX <= #### && absY >= 3300 && absY <=#### ))

So if you got the two next coordinates then do,

if((absX >= 2134 && absX <= 2145 && absY >= 3300 && absY <3312 ))

These were EXAMPLES.

Read full topic
